title: Could champions in the scoreboard be arranged automatically?
body:
Since in ranked and draft mode the game knows who plays where, it could automatically arrange champions on the scoreboard (the one that appears in game when you press tab) in the following order:
1. Top
2. Jungle
3. Mid
4. Bot (adc)
5. Support
The same way it is arranged in pro game casts, I believe.

[Edit] Or, even better, you could choose your own preferred order in the options.

[Edit2] Now that I think about it, maybe it shouldn't work for the enemy team, because it would reveal their strategy - the element of uncertainty of a flex pick can be a part of it. So maybe it should only apply to own team.

The way he has listed is standard order that's used in LCS.  The logic follows as

1. Top (because, well top)
2. Jungle (see other roles, it's the only spatial spot left)
3. Mid (put mid in the middle make sense?)
5. ADC
6. Support (our bot laners are at the bottom of the list)

This helps with visual reading of who's where without outside information on what role is where.  Its clean, clear, simple,  and effective graphically.  The way you have it organized is by some strange hierarchy of carry power, which we really don't care about when determining which champion is in what lane, but rather the actual spatiality of where that champion is.

Nope, the way I have it has nothing to do with carry power, It's just the lane positions Top, Mid and Bot placed on a list from top to bottom. After that we are left with two roles, so you place the support next to the ADC because they are a natural team and then Jungle falls into place last because its the only one left. Seems perfectly natural to me and has nothing to do with carry power, it just flows naturally.

Unlike the list of the LCS. I can understand placing Top at the top and Mid in the middle but why is ADC not placed at the bottom? Support isn't the true bot lane right? Support is just the extra in that lane that supports the real laner. It would look better if Support was 4 and ADC was 5.

Only thing I've seen against it (and it's a valid reason to not) is that it gives away vague picks. Like if one team's mid and top could go to either lane the other team would know which lane they are planning on going to based on their position in the scoreboard.

That is a pretty rare case although it is worth considering if they do something like this.
Put ADC on the bottom because they're listed as "Bot" and all ADC mains think they have to carry the weight of the team on their backs, placing them at the bottom of the list.

Consider that is is common practice in lcs to lane swap. Consider that in some games, there might be a 2v1 top or mid and a 1v2 bot. You might have one player per lane and two junglers. You might have a support who continuously roams. 

You might have the whole team walk up mid to begin with (maybe to invade jg) and then what, are they all configured mid? If not, how long would this system take to determine lanes and would it be constantly updating? That wouldn't be helpful after laning phase.

My point is that with the way different strategies are set up and the fact that riot doesn't technically enforce the meta, you're not guaranteed a top-mid-jg-supp-adc every game. 

The configuration on any system like this would be severely flawed because anyone could be in any lane at any given time. If it doesn't decide roles immediately (which would be flawed due to jg invades), then it could have a delay. However, then say it configures when the jg is ganking? Is he then a "top laner" to the system because he was too when it decided?

I just see so many things that would make the system wonky, unorganized, and just not worth the time it would take to implement (even if it's a small time). While I agree that in an ideal world, a system like this would be nice, I don't think it would be accurate even 50% of the time if it was implemented.

TLDR; Too many situations/strategies/off-meta situations happen that would make the system flawed or less useful. Good idea, but not a likely or realistic one. Even if riot could somehow fix all the factors that would impede accuracy, the likelihood that they'd even implement this is low.
